column5: we just take an oil thermometer.
Great idea!
Sour cream & onion Pringles - Pringles pack great and taste even better.Gor-tex rain gear - for obvious reasons.Cocoa mix - generally used the same days as the rain gear.
A big wad of sweaty money, Sirmanski and Captn Redbeard jigs. Rain gear, a bag of red and white Andys batter, peanut oil, sweet tater fries and deep woods off!
Canned pears to finish off shore lunch, nothing is quite as good. A good cookie or brownie can be close, but pears will spoil you for anything else.
If popcorn pops at 350 degrees will it not also pop at 400 or 450 degrees. How do you tell if it is too hot? Do you bring temperatures up slowly and then cut back the heat? Just wondering.

When it pops I throw in the fish. As long as I keep adding fish after removing the initial batch the oil seems to stay perfect. This is with a cast iron skillet, can't speak for those that deep fry...
- Corn Huskers hand lotion- 50 SPF sun screen- Noxzema to ease the sunburn sting- Old Grandad
I always take an electric fry pan. It's just seems a lot easier for frying fish than whatever might be in the kitchen at the lodge cabin and its lot easier to clean.

Hi Jig Man. Throw the kernel in before you start heating the oil. When it pops then you know you are at 350. Since I have used the deep fryer so much I can keep the oil pretty regulated by just watching how the oil rolls when the fish is added. To much roll, turn it down a bit.
Your son or daughter. Trips of a lifetime they will never forget nor yourself.

I got one of the ER doctor's I work with to give me a prescription for ODT zofran for nausea and cipro in case someone should develop some sort of infection. Leave in 2 days for my first trip. Can't wait!
I'm already in Canada but two items that have served us well on trips Large spools of back up line (1 of mono and 1 braid) Large roll of duct tape. Fixes anything lol
Andy's Red. Because you should have some crispy tasty Walleye to go along with your beer!
1. Portable Hummingbird GPS & fish locator. 2. Spinner rigs made with steel line 3. Good rain gear 4. Ultrathon insect repellent 5. Deep fry therometer
Good friends
Amen
A tank full of cheap (relatively) American gas.
Hey just a little tip regarding deep fry thermometer.A popcorn kernel pops at 350 deg. Use it to know when your oil is up to temp.
Barn matches lite at 350 alsoPaul
Been using popcorn for years. Half the time it pops right out of the pan so no need to fish it out....

1.A drift sock there are days when it works better for me to backtroll with a sock out front than run the bow mount trolling motor.Windy days or when it starts to get rough.2.White Mountain Insect repellant.Keeps biting flies,skeeters,no see ums and gnats away.Doesn't have DEET in it.Enuff said3.Bottombouncers and spinners.I can always take the beads and blade off and just fish a bouncer on a plain hook and live bait.4.Good rain gear.I finally got a good set of rain wear and it's a joy.5.My Berkley Ion rechargable fillet knife.Best knife I've used in the last 50 years of cleaning fish.6.IM 7 graphite bouncer rod and a Accurist Flippin switch reel.7.Last but not near least my wife.She has turned into a "good stick" in the last 2 years.Our friendly competition and her sense of humor just make the trip.Bill

Bill, the White Mountain Insect Repellant sounds interesting. After a week in Canada our Grandsons' hands are solid red and swollen from gnat bites. We haven't been able to find anything that stops him from getting attacked. Did you buy the White Mountain locally or order from their website?
I ordered it from their website.
We're thankful that we've never had to use it but we have an emergency overnight kit in the boat. Tarp, butane lighter, folding saw, bottled water, breakfast bars, etc.
Baby wipes..... You know, for those times when You just can't.....
Good hook file Hook cutters
The top two items on our list are: 1) Passports and Grandson's paperwork so we can get in and out of Canada. 2) Credit card and money so we can buy any necessities we forgot.

First aid kit with usual bandages, tape, antibacterial ointment, tweezers etc. plus a trusty little needle nose pliers/side cutter combo for cutting hardened trebles and removing them from your partner's flesh. Bourbon for pain relief/germ control. Don't forget some ibuprofen, allergy medicine, emergency iodine tabs, anti-diarrheal pills.Did anyone mention beer and ice to help embellish the beauty of the outdoors up north.

If your trip should coincide with the few weeks that the noseeums are out in force you will need 95% or better deet. Not available in Canada so always bring some with you. Ben's works. http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B000N02M9E/
Beer
